Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Developing an Imaging Tool to Investigate the Dynamics of Nanoparticles in 2D
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

Solutions, dispersions and gels play an important role in life and the physical sciences. These systems are important in areas ranging from the traditional, such as agriculture and cosmetics, to the cutting edge, such as new materials and nanomotors. This project will develop a new imaging technology that will allow us to visualize the motion of nanometer scale particles with high resolution for long periods of time. These studies will open a large number of opportunities in the imaging of nanoscopic materials across a range of materials areas. These include the crystallization of polymers in ultrathin films, polymer nanoparticle-composites, the diffusion of nanoparticles in gels, in situ monitoring of separations of nanoparticles and polymers, in operando monitoring of electrochemical cells for battery applications, 2D phase separation behavior, glassy and jammed nanoparticle assemblies, the dynamics of nonequilibrium systems, and in the monitoring of nanomotors, where propulsion is provided by chemical reactions. These studies will open pathways to addressing some of the most longstanding problems in materials and provide insight into controlling non-equilibrium packing of materials, including the dynamics and ageing of glassy materials, to structure/property relationships of glassy materials, and, ultimately, to the parameters that lead to rare events, like the unjamming of particles which can impact materials science but, also, area as far-reaching as geoscience, where such unjamming phenomena, as in the unjamming of tectonic plates, lead to earthquakes.

Technical Abstract

This project will develop a visualization protocol, along with the design of analysis routines and a revolutionary SEM sample cell to explore the dynamics of 2D assemblies of nanospheres (NSs) and nanorods (NRs) as the areal density of the nanoparticles (NPs) increases, bringing the NPs from a low density liquid state into a jammed or glassy state; along the way, structures and structure dynamics will be monitored at unprecedented spatial resolution. Imaging with electron microscopy provides the most valuable direct information on nanoscale structure. However, studies of typical solvated particles are limited by the high vapor pressure of the solvents which limits both spatial resolutions and the temporal duration of the studies. We will utilize ionic liquids (ILs) as an alternate platform to monitor solvated soft material dynamics by electron microscopy eliminating the need for a liquid cell. The proposed studies will advance our knowledge by developing instrumentation, versatile sample cell, and imaging software, to tackle a long-outstanding, truly grand challenge in materials science and physics, i.e., the nature of glassy and jammed systems. Through the development of the instrumentation and experimental protocols, we will gain insight into the dynamics of jammed and glassy materials, quantify the real-space structural rearrangements arising from NP interactions, and elucidate the heterogeneous nature of dynamics in glassy materials, a topic of intense theoretical interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscopic structures, tens to hundreds of times too small to visualize by optical microscopy, can be visualized by electron microscopy, but there is a catch – electron microscopy is a high vacuum method, precluding the study of ordinary liquid and solvated specimens because the liquid will evaporate. Thus, the nanoscopic structures of many materials, such as solvated gels, membranes, and growing small solution-grown crystals, have never been imaged.  We found that ionic liquids, a less common class of solvents characterized by nonvolatility, circumvent this predicament, retaining their liquid form in the electron microscope.  Even more, via the mobility endowed by the liquid’s presence, the structures these liquids solvate and disperse can move and deform, creating dynamics captured in electron microscope movies.  These types of dynamics underlie the properties of ‘soft matter’, a burgeoning class of materials that are potentially responsive, biocompatible, and tailorable to specific properties.

To illustrate the possibilities of electron microscopy with ionic liquids, in this project we used scanning electronic microscopy to study how nanoparticles move and arrange on a liquid interface, focusing on behaviors near the onset of two-dimensional nanoparticle jamming.  The new method has high enough spatial and temporal resolution to allow single particle tracking of thousands (or more) closely packed nanoparticles.  Of course, not all of these nanoparticles must be identical in size, shape, or chemistry, and we directed much attention to binary nanoparticle mixtures.  Among the interesting effects observed, well-mixed nanoparticles of different size were seen to segregate into separate nanostructures as the overall packing density approached jamming, a phenomenon neither predicted nor observed previously.  Attached Image 1 shows this effect for a near equal mixture of 145- and 200-nm spheres.  The small spheres, colorized in yellow, form interconnected clusters or domains of several particle diameters distributed among the better-dispersed larger spheres, colorized in green.  Attached Image 2 demonstrates comparable segregation in a near equal mixture of 100-nm spheres and 390x100-nm rods.  All of these particles were too small to be resolved by optical microscopy and imaging of such mixed packings would be impossible.  Here, imaging analysis software identified and tracked how each particle moved during the segregation as well as how the particles organized cooperatively with growing density.

Soft matter systems can rearrange in response to external actions, and for the interfacial nanoparticle systems chosen for this study, a key action is change of surface area, which can alternately cause compression and de-compression of a particle layer.  We built and optimized a liquid cell that fits into the microscope chamber and imposes controlled changes in interfacial area during imaging.  Using the cell, systems were brought from disordered to jammed states and back again.  If kept jammed for a short time, de-compression simply reversed compression, but if kept for a longer time, de-compression induced cracking, a response suggesting coalescence of the jammed nanoparticles into a two-dimensional, solid-like layer.  The precise arrangement of particles around a crack was discernable, pointing toward future studies of nanoscale crack propagation.

In developing the electron microscopy method, problems such as beam damage, charging (due to deposition of electrons in liquid specimens), nanoparticle dispersion, and imaging contrast were successfully overcome.  One complication, viewed equally as a problem and an opportunity, was interaction of the electron beam with metal or metal-coated nanoparticles.  This interaction, only seen above a threshold beam current, induced the imaged nanoparticles to aggregate in the center of the field of view.  The same interaction can be viewed as means to assemble nanoparticles into precisely ordered structures, framing another future project.   The non-conducting inorganic oxide nanoparticles probed in the majority of current project experiments did not interact with the electron beam.

While establishing a new imaging method of unprecedented capabilities for soft matter, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a post-doctoral fellow, gained sophisticated training in imaging and nanotechnology.  In summary, all project objectives were met, with a new nanoscale imaging tool for solvated specimens made available to the broader science community and a new understanding gained in how densely packed particles jam in two dimensions.
